questions.question:
What happens when Python runs this line?

print("The hero awakens!")
options: Draws a picture of the hero
Saves the text in a file

questions.question: Which is the correct way to make the computer speak?

What will this code display?

print("The hero has", 50, "coins.")

The villagers are waiting to hear your voice.
Write Python code that prints these two sentences on separate lines:
1. The hero awakens!
2. The adventure begins...
questions.sample_solution:
print("The hero awakens!")
print("The adventure begins...")

questions.question:
The guild scroll shows the hero's stats.
Write one line of code that prints:
The hero has 100 HP.
Hint: Use both text and numbers together with commas.

Write a 3-line prologue that tells the story of your hero waking up.
Be creative! Describe the village, the villagers, or the hero's first action.
questions.sample_solution:
print("The hero awakens in a small village.")
print("The villagers gather around.")
print("The journey begins!")

questions.question: Which symbol starts a comment in Python?
Why do we use comments in Python programs?
options: To explain the code to humans
To make the computer talk louder

questions.question:
The guild master asks you to add a note before your code.
At the top, write a comment: # This is my first Python program
Then print: The guild welcomes the hero!
questions.sample_solution:
# This is my first Python program
print("The guild welcomes the hero!")

questions.question:
Add a helpful note to your quest scroll.
Do the following:
1. Write a comment describing what your code does.
2. Write a print() line that shows: Welcome to Pythonia!
questions.sample_solution:
# Prints a welcome message to the new hero
print("Welcome to Pythonia!")

questions.question: Which of the following correctly creates a variable storing the hero's HP as 120?

If you run this code, what is printed?

hero_hp = 100
hero_hp = 80
print(hero_hp)
Create a variable hero_coins = 50 and print: "The hero carries 50 coins."
Which data type is best for storing whether a hero is alive or dead?

What is the output?

hero_level = 5
print(type(hero_level))
Create variables hero_level = 2 (int) and hero_speed = 3.5 (float). Print both stats in one line.
questions.sample_solution:
hero_level = 2
hero_speed = 3.5
print("Level:", hero_level, "| Speed:", hero_speed)

questions.question: Which command correctly prints both hero_name and hero_hp?

What will this code display?

hero_name = "Kai"
hero_hp = 90
print("Hero:", hero_name, "| HP:", hero_hp)
Create a variable hero_weapon = "Iron Sword" and print: "The hero swings an Iron Sword!"
questions.sample_solution:
hero_weapon = "Iron Sword"
print("The hero swings an", hero_weapon + "!")

questions.question:
What will this program print?

hero_name = "Luna"
hero_hp = 70
hero_alive = True
print("Name:", hero_name)
print("HP:", hero_hp)
print("Alive:", hero_alive)
options:
Name: hero_name
HP: hero_hp
Alive: hero_alive

questions.question:
Create a hero profile using different data types:
- hero_name = "Milo" (string)
- hero_hp = 120 (int)
- hero_attack = 7.5 (float)
- hero_alive = False (boolean)
Print all stats in one formatted block.
questions.sample_solution:
hero_name = "Milo"
hero_hp = 120
hero_attack = 7.5
hero_alive = False

print("Hero Card")
print("---------")
print("Name:", hero_name)
print("HP:", hero_hp)
print("Attack:", hero_attack)
print("Alive:", hero_alive)

quiz_data.quiz_title: Week 3 Quiz – Speak with the Villagers

questions.question: What does the input() function do in Python?
options: Displays a message on the screen

questions.question: What is printed if the player types 'Luna'?

content.text:
hero_name = input("What is your name? ")
print("Welcome,", hero_name)

questions.expected_answer:
What is your name? Luna
Welcome, Luna

questions.question: Ask the player for their village name using input() and print: “You come from <village>.”
questions.expected_answer:
village = input("What village are you from? ")
print("You come from", village + ".")

questions.question: Why do we use int() or float() when reading numbers from input?
options: To convert text into numbers for math

questions.question: What will be printed if the player enters 10?

content.text:
coins = int(input("How many coins? "))
coins += 5
print("Now you have", coins, "coins.")

questions.expected_answer:
How many coins? 10
Now you have 15 coins.

questions.question: Ask for hero’s attack (float), add 1.5 (training bonus), then print the result.
questions.expected_answer:
hero_attack = float(input("Enter hero attack: "))
hero_attack += 1.5
print("After training, attack is", hero_attack)

questions.question: Which option correctly prints a message using an f-string?
What will this program display?

content.text:
hero_name = "Kai"
hero_hp = 100
print(f"Welcome {hero_name}! You have {hero_hp} HP.")

questions.expected_answer: Welcome Kai! You have 100 HP.

questions.question: Ask for the hero’s name, then print a message: “{name} is ready for battle!” using an f-string.
questions.expected_answer:
hero_name = input("What is your hero's name? ")
print(f"{hero_name} is ready for battle!")

questions.question: What will be displayed if the player types: Arin, 12, 7.5?

content.text:
hero_name = input("Name: ")
hero_coins = int(input("Coins: "))
hero_attack = float(input("Attack: "))
print(f"Welcome {hero_name}! You have {hero_coins} coins and {hero_attack} attack power.")

questions.expected_answer:
Name: Arin
Coins: 12
Attack: 7.5
Welcome Arin! You have 12 coins and 7.5 attack power.

questions.question:
Create a short interactive hero intro:
- Ask for hero_name (str), hero_coins (int), and hero_attack (float).
- Print all three stats neatly using f-strings.
questions.expected_answer:
hero_name = input("Hero name: ")
hero_coins = int(input("Coins: "))
hero_attack = float(input("Attack power: "))
print(f"Welcome {hero_name}! Coins: {hero_coins}, Attack: {hero_attack}")

questions.question: Add a bonus: after the player enters attack, increase it by 2.5 and print the new value using f-strings.
questions.expected_answer:
hero_attack = float(input("Enter hero attack: "))
hero_attack += 2.5
print(f"Your boosted attack power is {hero_attack}")

quiz_data.quiz_title: Week 4 Quiz – The Hero’s First Choice (Conditionals)

questions.question: What will this code print if the player inputs 'RUN'?
If hero_choice = 'SLEEP', what happens?
Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer: You toss coins!

questions.question: What will this code print?
What is the output?
questions.expected_answer: You buy the potion!

questions.question: What’s the output?
questions.expected_answer: Bonus unlocked!

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.expected_answer: Monster defeated!

questions.question: What will this code print?
Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer: Halfway there!

questions.question: What will this code print if the player inputs 'RUN'?
If hero_choice = 'SLEEP', what happens?
Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer: You toss coins!

questions.question: What will this code print?
What is the output?
questions.expected_answer: You buy the potion!

questions.question: What’s the output?
questions.expected_answer: Bonus unlocked!

questions.question: What is the output?
questions.expected_answer: Monster defeated!

questions.question: What will this code print?
Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer: Halfway there!

questions.question: What does the following code print?

content.text:
for i in range(3):
    print('Hit the dummy!')

questions.question: Write a for loop that prints 'Attack!' five times.

content.text:
for i in range(5):
    print('Attack!')

questions.expected_answer:
for i in range(5):
    print('Attack!')

questions.question: How many lines are printed?

content.text:
for turn in range(1, 4):
    print('Turn', turn)

questions.question:
Write code that prints:
Turn 1
Turn 2
Turn 3
Turn 4

content.text:
for t in range(1, 5):
    print('Turn', t)

questions.expected_answer:
for t in range(1, 5):
    print('Turn', t)

questions.question: How many 'Hit!' lines are printed?

content.text:
monster_hp = 10
while monster_hp > 0:
    print('Hit!')
    monster_hp -= 4

questions.question: Create a while loop that counts down from 3 to 1 and prints each number.

content.text:
num = 3
while num > 0:
    print(num)
    num -= 1

questions.expected_answer:
num = 3
while num > 0:
    print(num)
    num -= 1

questions.question: What is printed at the end?
Write a for loop from 1–5 but break at turn 4.
What is the output?
Write a loop for turns 1–4 that skips turn 2.
Create a while loop with orc_hp = 30. Subtract 9 each turn. Stop if orc_hp < 10 using break.

content.text:
orc_hp = 30
while orc_hp > 0:
    print('Orc HP:', orc_hp)
    orc_hp -= 9
    if orc_hp < 10:
        break
print('Orc flees!')

questions.expected_answer:
orc_hp = 30
while orc_hp > 0:
    print('Orc HP:', orc_hp)
    orc_hp -= 9
    if orc_hp < 10:
        break
print('Orc flees!')

questions.question: Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer:
Turn 1
Drink potion!
Turn 3
Monster surrenders!

content.text:
for i in range(3):
    print('Hit the dummy!')

content.text:

questions.expected_answer:

questions.question: Predict the output.

content.text:
for i in range(2, 10, 3):
    print(i)

questions.question: How many 'Hit!' lines are printed?

content.text:
monster_hp = 10
while monster_hp > 0:
    print('Hit!')
    monster_hp -= 4

questions.question: Create a while loop that counts down from 3 to 1 and prints each number.

content.text:
num = 3
while num > 0:
    print(num)
    num -= 1

questions.expected_answer:
num = 3
while num > 0:
    print(num)
    num -= 1

questions.question: Predict the output.

content.text:
hp = 10
while hp < 20:
    hp += 5
    print(hp)

questions.question: What is printed at the end?
Write a for loop from 1–5 but break at turn 4.
Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer:
Attack!
Rat flees!

questions.question: What is the output?
Write a loop for turns 1–4 that skips turn 2.
Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer:
Greg fights turn 1
Greg fights turn 2
Greg fights turn 3
Greg fights turn 5

questions.question: Which statement best describes 'break' and 'continue'?
options: break stops all loops, continue repeats the same step
break stops the current loop, continue skips the rest of current iteration
break restarts the loop, continue exits program

questions.question: Create a while loop with orc_hp = 30. Subtract 9 each turn. Stop if orc_hp < 10 using break.

content.text:
orc_hp = 30
while orc_hp > 0:
    print('Orc HP:', orc_hp)
    orc_hp -= 9
    if orc_hp < 10:
        break
print('Orc flees!')

questions.expected_answer:
orc_hp = 30
while orc_hp > 0:
    print('Orc HP:', orc_hp)
    orc_hp -= 9
    if orc_hp < 10:
        break
print('Orc flees!')

questions.question: Predict the output.
questions.expected_answer:
Turn 1
Drink potion!
Turn 3
Monster surrenders!
